answer_html: Since the function is only defined in the interval \((-2,2)\), which is bound on both sides, the function does not have horizontal asymptotes.
answer_latex:
Since the function is only defined in the interval $(-2,2)$, which is
bound on both sides, the function does not have horizontal asymptotes.
hints_html: Remember that we find asymptotes using limits. Horizontal asymptotes are found by taking the limit of the function at positive and negative infinity. Vertical asymptotes are found by taking the limit of the function at points where the function is not defined - specifically endpoints of the domain.
hints_latex:
Remember that we find asymptotes using limits. Horizontal asymptotes are
found by taking the limit of the function at positive and negative
infinity. Vertical asymptotes are found by taking the limit of the
function at points where the function is not defined - specifically
endpoints of the domain.
hints_raw: Remember that we find asymptotes using limits.  Horizontal asymptotes are found by taking the limit of the function at positive and negative infinity.  Vertical asymptotes are found by taking the limit of the function at points where the function is not defined - specifically endpoints of the domain.
question: 8 (b)
sols_html:
To find vertical asymptotes, we will take the limit of the function at \(x = 2\) and \(x = -2\). Note that we are taking one-sided limits because the function is not defined on both sides of the point.

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to -2^+} \ln(4-x^2)\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 2^-} \ln(4-x^2)\end{aligned}\]

As \(x\) goes to -2 (from the right) or 2 (from the left), the expression \(4-x^2 \rightarrow 0^+\). So using \(y = 4-x^2\) we can rewrite both of these limits as

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{y \to 0^+} \ln(y)\end{aligned}\]

which is simply \(-\infty\). So the function has vertical asymptotes at both \(x = -2\) and \(x=2\).

Since the function is only defined in the interval \((-2,2)\), which is bound on both sides, the function does not have horizontal asymptotes.
sols_raw:
To find vertical asymptotes, we will take the limit of the function at <math>x = 2</math> and <math>x = -2</math>.  Note that we are taking one-sided limits because the function is not defined on both sides of the point.  

:<math>\lim_{x \to -2^+} \ln(4-x^2) </math>

:<math>\lim_{x \to 2^-} \ln(4-x^2) </math>

As <math>x</math> goes to -2 (from the right) or 2 (from the left), the expression <math>4-x^2 \rightarrow 0^+</math>.  So using <math>y = 4-x^2</math> we can rewrite both of these limits as

:<math>\lim_{y \to 0^+} \ln(y)</math>

which is simply <math>-\infty</math>.  So the function has vertical asymptotes at both <math>x = -2</math> and <math>x=2</math>.  

Since the function is only defined in the interval <math>(-2,2)</math>, which is bound on both sides, the function does not have horizontal asymptotes.
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \ln\left(4-x^2\right)\end{aligned}\]

Find all the vertical and horizontal asymptotes of \(f\), if there are any.
statement_raw:
Let

:<math> \displaystyle
f(x) = \ln\left(4-x^2\right)
</math>

Find all the vertical and horizontal asymptotes of &fnof;, if there are any.
